MIKE: So, Paris,
it's absolutely great to get a chance to
chat with you today,

and I want to start
off by saying thanks for joining us from Madrid.

So for those on the
webinar that have seen previous webinars
associated with this program

[AUDIO OUT] series of
webinars for the i2M program
that focus on a range of topics.

And so the topics
have included things like what are the top 10
things you should look

for in a venture
capitalist or what are some of the specific
tips to getting funding.

And in this case, we're going
to be talking about something that's really important for
entrepreneurs to understand,

and that is the
topic of resilience. Specifically,
personal resilience.

And so as Anita had
mentioned, I am a professor

in the School of
Engineering at Stanford and serve as academic
director for a lot of our entrepreneurship and
venture capital training

programs. But, Paris, why don't
you introduce yourself to us in a little more detail,
specifically talking about IE,

if folks aren't familiar
with the IE Business School. Venture Lab, what
you're doing [AUDIO OUT] And then after that, we can talk
a little bit about your journey

and history of
personal resilience. PARIS: OK. Thanks, Mike.

It's a pleasure to be here. Yeah, IE Business School
is a top 20 business

school in the world and
we're based in Madrid. We probably have some of
the highest diversity rates

of any school in the world. About 95% of our
students are not Spanish

and classes are in English. The Entrepreneurship Center,
which I run with the Venture

Lab, is number one in
Europe for business schools and we're ranked about
four or five in the world.

So we take entrepreneurship
very seriously. The Venture Lab-- I've been running the Venture
Lab for the last 12 years.

Over 1,500 startups have
come through the Venture Lab in the last 12 years.

We have about close to a
couple hundred every year.

So essentially, what we find is
that about 30% of our alumni,

from 25% to 30%, actually
become entrepreneurs.

Essentially, we do
drink the Kool-Aid here. We push people beyond
their boundaries

to think like entrepreneurs. And a lot of them, they
get the bug in them, and by the time
they graduate, they

want to become entrepreneurs
or two or three years down the line. And so it's pretty
serious stuff,

and the Venture Lab works across
the school, undergraduates in the technology
school, the master's

in management, the MBA. So yeah, it's a pretty busy
lab, and I can say this.

It's been a hell of
a roller coaster ride over the last few years. And especially
during the pandemic, we found that more
and more people

wanted to become entrepreneurs. MIKE: Yeah, indeed. We're certainly seeing
the same things here.

And once again, I
want to thank you for joining us from a little
bit later in the day for you. It's really this access to
world-class global experts

that I think makes
the i2M program, specifically, really special. And your involvement in it
as one of the instructors

and also one of the participants
in our webinar series, really special. So I want to first
take a minute and focus

on your personal journey
because the work that you've done to try to help
entrepreneurs understand

this idea of
resilience and mindset is not one that is purely
academic in nature,

even though you are
a faculty member at a world-class
business school. It's one of a personal
journey from you as well.

And so I think it'd be helpful
to take a few minutes to talk about that personal
journey that you've

had to get to this point. And then we can jump off
into some of the findings that your research and our
collaborative work to date
have resulted in. PARIS: OK. Yeah, you're right. I am not your typical academic.

Actually, my background
is I grew up in LA and I decided to go
to school in Boston.

I went to BU, Boston University. I did my bachelor's
in mathematics there and then I got my master's
work in computer science there.

And so, as you can
see, when I graduated, I was pretty much a nerd. I hated uncertainty in my work.

And I also hated it
in my personal life. I always tell the story of
my first girlfriend, Bonnie.

I was 17 and she
actually left me because she said I was too
boring and too predictable.

She said-- I always used
to call her at 8 o'clock and I was like, well, what time
do you want me to call you? And she says, well, can't
you call me at 8:15?

That might actually create
some excitement in our lives. Yeah. So I was pretty nerdy.

And it was then that I
realized that when you're nerdy and you don't like
uncertainty in your personal

and your professional life,
it's got ramifications. And so what I saw very
clearly when I was doing--

I got my first job. And when I graduated
in programming, I saw very clearly that
I needed to find a way
to understand business better. I had to unnerd somehow. And I got really lucky.

A colleague of mine from
Harvard that was just across the river there, he
called me up and he said,

Paris, I'd like you to come to
New York City and work with me. I'd like you to run the
sales desk in my real estate
investment firm. And I said, sales? I mean, I'm a nerd. I can't do sales.

And so he took me through this
incredible training program,

which I'm not going to
bore you with tonight, but you can read
about it in my thesis or also some other
TEDx's that I've done.

But essentially, he put me
through a six-month training program that unnerded me. I was forced out of my
comfort zone repeatedly.

And that-- I realized then
that it was like a muscle. The more you stretch this
muscle of pushing yourself out

of your comfort zone
and trying to understand other forms of business,
essentially, what I was doing

is-- well, before, since I was
so obsessed with certainty, I saw fear.

I had fear with uncertainty. Now, for the first time
after this training program, I saw opportunity
in uncertainty.

And that's truly what
differentiates an entrepreneur

from most people. MIKE: And this is, I
guess, a little bit of a prelude into
what we're going

to be talking about in these
foundations of entrepreneurship is this mindset of is it
opportunity or is it fear

of uncertainty in
how you view this. We'll get to those
in a little bit. So you're in New York. You've done this
training program.

I guess I would say nothing
wrong with being a nerd. It's a wonderful way
to get great jobs

and have a wonderful
life, but, yeah, it's a different [AUDIO OUT].

So you do this training. Then what happened? PARIS: Well, I
joined his investment

firm, his real estate
investment firm, and I was only
there for six months when I got a call
from Wall Street

and some guy at Union Bank of
Switzerland said to me, listen, we've heard you're a
pretty good salesman.
And I said, wow. All the way in Wall Street. And so I went to see them.

They made me an offer
I couldn't refuse. I went back to my boss. I said, what do I do? And he said, listen,
you've done your bit here.

Your future's in banking. And that started my career
in investment banking. I spent the '80s
in New York City.

And you probably read
a lot of those books, Liar's Poker and the rest. Those were the most amazing
years in New York City.

I was not a nice person
during those years. I got to admit that.

MIKE: There was also a
movie with Michael Douglas and some other things
about that time. PARIS: That's right. MIKE: And so, yeah, a
very interesting time

in Wall Street. PARIS: I was not a good
guy during those years. So after 10 years in New York
doing investment banking,

I ended up in London
at ABN AMRO Bank. Also doing investment banking. And then I became 42 in 2002
and I decided I had enough.

I became what I call
a Friday person. And I tell this a
lot to my students.

I think there are two types
of people in the world, Friday people and Monday people.

And whenever I've-- I've always
loved Mondays because I love what I do.

And the reality is that
40% of our life is work. So if you don't
love what you do, I mean, that's a sad reality.

But the reality is that most
people are Friday people. I mean, you look at
them on Thursdays, they're smiling because they're
looking forward to the weekend.

And so I became a Friday
person in 2002 and I said, I got to get out of
this racket, and I

was very lucky to get the
call from Sony in Japan. They said to me that
Manchester United had canceled

their friendly
match and they were looking for an entrepreneur
to bring European football

teams to Japan. Now I knew nothing about soccer
football and, as an American, I didn't even like soccer.

But that night,
I couldn't sleep. I said to myself, this is it. This is my opportunity.

And I went to my wife
and I said, honey, I'm leaving the bank. And she said, oh, really?

Where are you going? Goldman Sachs? Morgan Stanley, maybe? And I said, no, I'm going
to become a sports marketing

professional. You should have seen her face. So that started my eight-year
sprint as an entrepreneur.
I had five startups. One in sports. Did pretty well. One in advertising agency.
Lost a lot of money. Renewable energy one. That did well. A CRM company software.

That did well. And then I also did the
first-person shooter game on Xbox Kinect, video game.

That was a disaster. I lost a fortune, you know? And so after eight years
of being an entrepreneur,
I became a Friday person again. I got fed up. I said--

MIKE: I think it's
really important that folks on the call also
hear from successful academic,

successful entrepreneurs
that not everything is a series of successes and
in many, many regards,

entrepreneurship is a resilience
exercise in understanding how to learn from failure
and see failure as a growth

opportunity just as much
as it is the ability to move on to the next thing. So I appreciate you
honestly sharing the fact

that you know what? That failed and it was
a flaming disaster. And so that's really important.

Thanks for sharing. PARIS: And you learn. MIKE: Keep going. So your [AUDIO OUT] PARIS: And so, yeah,
I decided I was

going to become a professor. And you should have
seen my wife's face when I told her, honey, I have
become a Friday person again.

I want to teach. And she looked at
me and said, you know, Paris, most people,
when they change careers,

they make more money. And you have gone, I mean,
from being an investment banker where we were rich
to being an entrepreneur

where we didn't know when
the next paycheck was coming to being a professor where
we know that that paycheck is

going to be very small. MIKE: Yeah. Where we know there's
no paycheck coming. [LAUGHTER]

PARIS: Exactly. And so for the last 12
years, I've been here at IE

running the Venture
Lab and working alongside the
Entrepreneurship Center.

But the big thing that
really pertains to this talk is my thesis. I decided-- and I
had to get a PhD

because if you want to be a
teacher, you got to be a PhD. Otherwise, they were going
to look at me and say, you're just some
ex-investment banker.

And so my thesis
director at the time-- I got my PhD in Spain
in Barcelona at Esade.

to find a topic that
you can relate to. And essentially, when I told him
the story of my life, he said,

listen, you've got to talk
about the relationship that we have with uncertainty.

And essentially,
I studied nerds. I studied those people that
struggle with ambiguity, that

are obsessed with certainty. And I got to the
point where I was able to understand the
difference between one's

relationship with uncertainty
in their personal life and their professional life.

And so I look at myself. I haven't changed a lot
in my personal life. I'm pretty much--
I'm not a nerd,

but I'm more nerdy than not. But in my professional
life, ever since I did that training
program back then,

I just embrace uncertainty. And that's why I think
this talk of resilience

in entrepreneurship
is really critical.

MIKE: And I think this
talk of resilience and entrepreneurship,
particularly as it stretches

into our personal life,
is even more important right now during the
pandemic when there is indeed

a lot of uncertainty related
to our professional lives. And for those that
are entrepreneurs, that level of uncertainty
is always there,

but you layer that on
with increased uncertainty in our personal lives.

And I would imagine,
and I know this to be the case, for
many entrepreneurs, it's overwhelming
because where you

seemed to have control and
less uncertainty in your life. And I know in our
previous discussions,

you've talked about this
balance between being OK with uncertainty
in one aspect of maybe

your professional life, but
needing less uncertainty in your personal life
to provide that balance.

During the pandemic,
that control over the level of uncertainty
in our personal lives

has indeed been taken
from us, and that's why this topic
today of developing

resilient mindsets for
entrepreneurs I think is so important.

PARIS: Totally, Mike. And back to the pandemic. What we have seen in the
research that we've done,

we've seen that very
much during the pandemic, we've been forced to get more
comfortable with uncertainty.

We've been forced to
feel less fear about it. I mean, it was like a
train wreck hitting us

at the beginning
of the pandemic. But at the same time, we're
looking for less uncertainty

in our personal lives. I mean, I had a student
of mine, an undergraduate, and I'll never forget this guy.

He was German. And before the pandemic, I
mean, the guy was partying crazy and one of his projects
that he wanted to build

was a dating app because
he thought that dating apps had not advanced enough.

And so the pandemic hits. And after lockdown,
we come back. We start having
online classes and I

see the guy completely
pivot hit dating site. And then go like,
what's going on here?

He says, I'm going to
build a site that actually is going to help couples
create serious, long-lasting
relationships. The guy is 18.

And I'm asking him,
so what are you looking for in a relationship? And he says, commitment. And I'm like, what
does commitment

mean for an 18-year-old? I mean, that's an extreme
example, but so many people,

they either bought a pet. I mean, why did pets go crazy? I mean, pets became family
members during the pandemic.

Everybody was searching for
more meaning in their lives during the pandemic
and they were

trying to reflect on what
was important to them. I mean, we've come out of
this much richer as humans.

We've come out of
this having a better sense of what's important
and what isn't with respect

to our personal lives, and
that's moved us far to the left in terms of wanting more
certainty in our lives.

But professionally, it's been
like a train wreck, as I said. And so what we're
seeing is more and more

people are embracing
uncertainty now and they're realizing
that they have to

and they have to see
opportunity in it. And that's going
to take resilience
because this is all about fear. MIKE: Absolutely, absolutely.

One of the things
that we absolutely want to do with every
single one of our webinars in this series related to i2M
is leave folks with something

of really high value. And often, we find that to be
things like checklists, things

like small little guidelines,
something simple they can walk away from and trying
to improve who

they are as an entrepreneur. Because within our
programs, we're really focused on frameworks.

We're really focused
on giving people tools for how they should think.

We can't answer every question
an entrepreneur would have. Everybody [AUDIO OUT] different.

Therefore, these small
tools and frameworks to help folks think
about what they're doing

is what we really
like to focus on because we find that to be
a fundamentally sound way to teach entrepreneurship.

And so we've talked
about five underpinnings of entrepreneurial resilience.

So I'm going to sort of walk
us through these, 1 through 5, and I'd love to hear your
thoughts [AUDIO OUT] why

do you think each
one of these is so important, from
the work you've done, your personal history, the
research you've done at IE,

and your experience
at Venture Lab. And so the first
one, and it's one we've alluded to
already in some regards,

is the first underpinning, see
opportunity in uncertainty.

The entrepreneur has
to see uncertainty as a source of opportunity,
not a source of fear.

Can you talk a
little about what you mean by that and
some examples where you've seen folks, including
yourself, do that effectively?

PARIS: OK. And this is a very
important point. I like to put it in the
context of your comfort zone.

We've heard forever people say,
get out of your comfort zone, but everybody
struggles with that.

And why do they
struggle with it? Because inherently, they don't
want to change as a person

many times. And so if you were able
to disconnect the personal

from the professional, it
would be a completely different story. If now I ask you get out of
your professional comfort zone,

you're like, sure. What do I have to do? You want me to speak in public? You want me to go down the
hall and talk to a stranger

and find out about-- hang
out with the marketing people if I'm a bit of a nerd?

So you can deal with that. But if I ask you get out of
your personal comfort zone

and you're a nerd and
you're on the dance floor and I'm telling you
to go up to some girl and ask her for a dance, that's
a completely different story.

And so since this
is all about fear, we can manage our
professional fears. It's very difficult to
manage your personal fears.

And so-- MIKE: I think this bifurcation
of personal and professional and saying, look,
you can stay who

you are and true to
yourself, authentic, while allowing yourself to grow.

And by separating these,
giving people the freedom to embrace uncertainty. One of the questions that came
in from the audiences, what

tactic can help us
embrace uncertainty? I think you just provided one. Bifurcate-- PARIS: Totally. MIKE: --the-- you think
about uncertainty.

PARIS: Bifurcate, anchor. You need to anchor
who you are, OK? Now you were saying
earlier that what

we've found, the balance here. We've studied over 20,000
people over the last 10 years

and we have found that
80% of the people who embrace uncertainty in
their professional life,

entrepreneurs,
innovators, they're nerds in their personal life.

They don't like uncertainty. The late Steve Jobs,
he denied uncertainty

in his personal life. He embraced it professionally. Guys like Mark Zuckerberg
Richard Branson,

all these guys. They're more nerdy in
their personal lives and they're embracing
it professionally. So the reality is that we
look for balance in our lives.

And so that makes total sense. But the sad thing
today, and this is one of the key
messages for young people,

is that if you're nerdy, if
you're introverted, you're shy, society and your parents,
everybody's telling you

you should maybe be
an engineer or be a mathematician or an auditor.

But the reality
is that if you are nerdy in your personal life,
you have a better chance

of going crazy in your
professional life in being a leader, or an entrepreneur, or
a unicorn founder, you name it.

MIKE: Yeah. Indeed, indeed. All right, so the first one,
see opportunity in uncertainty.

And an important part of
that, as best you can, bifurcating so that you
can view that uncertainty

as an opportunity. All right, so the second
one that you've identified, and I think is an interesting
one to talk about,

harness the emotions of others. And can you talk a
little bit about what

you mean by harnessing
the emotions of others? Because [AUDIO OUT] about
taking advantage of people,

but rather, how do
you, in fact, see emotion and the
connection of emotion

to uncertainty as
an opportunity.

PARIS: Well, let me tell you. What we found also is
that the more comfortable you are with uncertainty, the
more emotional intelligence

you have because there's nothing
more uncertain than people's emotions.

And so we're living
in a world today where a very key
part of resilience

is your emotional intelligence,
and more and more companies are realizing that
this is critical.

And this is from every
angle that you look at. Let me give you one
angle, for example.

Much of innovation today

millennials, about 50% of them

prefer the user experience
to the actual product. And why is that?

Because we're living
in a world today where young people
and everybody, but, in particular,
young people,

everybody is looking for
meaning in their lives.

And if you want to give
people meaning in their lives, you have to give them something

People are more
concerned about how you make them feel
than what you're doing or how you're doing it.

It's like the Simon Sinek stuff. It's the why because the why
is what gives people meaning.

I mean, you take your
average secretary in Japan. She makes $40,000
a year, but she's

got a Louis Vuitton bag and
a Rolex watch that, together, are worth more than $10,000.

It gives them meaning. And that's why luxury is
such a key factor today

in so many people's lives. But from all these
big companies,

whether it's
Amazon, whether it's Alexa, all these things
that we're doing out there,

it's all about giving
people meaning. And if you can create user
experiences that give people

meaning, you're going
to get customers and you'll be able to build a

best phone in the world or the fastest phone.

But you know what? I have a relationship

people's emotions is

about being able to give them
meaning and understanding what gives people meaning. And that's why we need young
people to really develop

their emotional
intelligence, and you can do that in a professional setting. It's a lot harder in

but you can learn emotional
intelligence at work. MIKE: Absolutely. This is something that we
know we can do training on

and there's a lot of
opportunities in those spaces. I think it's also a very
important point when you're

talking about user experience. For many entrepreneurs,
you're so product-focused.

What are the features
of the product? What's my MVP? Kind of going along
through your checklist.

And it's often easy to forget
about that user experience and that the sale
of product is more

about value creation
for your customer than it is about a checklist
of awesome features

that you can provide to them. And even for B2B customers. You're still dealing with an

a B2C or B2B business, I think this [AUDIO OUT]
of the emotions of others

All right, so the
next thing that you highlight in this list of five. So first was see
opportunity in uncertainty.

And I'll continue
to repeat these so we kind of keep going
through these five. The second was harness
the emotions of others.

The third, making sure

the why, Simon Sinek's why,

in the sense that people are
not interested in what you do

or how you do it but
why you do what you do. And like I said, a lot of people

Now when you love what you
do, it doesn't feel like work. And that's why-- entrepreneurs

decide for yourself.

meaning in your life in order to do the things

rather than a paycheck, a TGIF,
